awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Residual Stress Preserved in Crystals from Volcanic Eruptions
awd_abstract_narration:
Volcanic eruptions transport magma from reservoirs deep underground to the surface through conduits.  Because volcanic processes occur underground, or are very dangerous to approach, many key aspects of volcanic eruptions are difficult to study with direct observations. Here, a new technology called synchrotron X-ray micro diffraction (microXRD) will be used to document deformation preserved in crystals that were transported within volcanic eruptions. The microXRD technique measures the amount of strain and preserved stress in the crystal lattice of those crystals. Volcanic stresses are important because they control eruption processes, including magma movement and explosivity. The first step to interpreting residual stress is to identify the specific processes that strain volcanic crystals. To this end, volcanic simulation experiments will be performed to deform crystals. MicroXRD will be used to analyze the experimental products and then compare results with natural crystals. This set of experiments and measurements will address the "How" and "Why" of volcanic eruptions. The standards and techniques developed in this project will enable application of microXRD to other disciplines, including Tectonics, Meteoritics, and Materials Science.  


The forces that act on magmas control volcanic processes. Consequently, crystals from volcanic eruptions are strained in the magma chamber, conduit, and during emplacement. Synchrotron X-ray micro diffraction (microXRD) will be used to quantify the magnitude of those strains by analyzing crystal lattice deformation with submicron spatial resolution on a suite of quartz, magnetite, and zircon crystals from the Long Valley and Yellowstone calderas. Measuring the magnitude of strains and using microstructure maps across crystals will reveal how strain is produced and preserved in crystals. Next, the preserved strains will be translated to causal stresses using the elastic constants of the mineral and Hooke's law. The goal is to quantify volcanic stresses in different volcanic environments and assess the forces and the time scales over which those forces act. MicroXRD has exceptional potential as an emerging technology in the geological sciences, but there is limited physical and theoretical infrastructure to interpret datasets. For this reason, high-temperature experiments will be performed to simulate stresses in volcanic environments using unstrained synthetic crystals, and assess the preservation of stress in strained natural crystals. Experimental products will be analyzed by microXRD and used to identify and/or eliminate sources of deformation.

por.por_cntn:
Magma ascent and volcanic eruptions are driven by a set of internally and externally generated  forces that act upon the magma. The magnitudes of these forces remain poorly constrained because they operate in regions that are inaccessible, either underground or dangerous to approach. Those forces and eruption dynamics, however, can also be encoded in the magmas that erupt, within crystals and inclusions of melt and gas trapped inside the crystals.

 

New techniques are needed to quantify the processes that drive eruptions and to probe magma storage conditions. In this project we used novel measurements made with X-ray imaging from a synchrotron source at the Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley National Lab. We studied quartz crystals from super-eruptions in California, Yellowstone, New Mexico, and Indonesia.

Using synchrotron-sourced X-ray microdiffraction measurements, we mapped volcanic stress imparted as lattice distortions in quartz crystals and measured elastic stress and plastic deformation. By analyzing crystals from pyroclastic falls, pyroclastic density currents, and effusive lavas we showed that the stress recorded in the crystals is recording brittle failure of viscous, crystal-bearing magma during ascent and hence we obtain a measure of the stresses leading to explosive eruption. By studying the crystal lattice around melt inclusions, whose morphology has a relationship to time that is largely independent of stress state, we obtain additional information about the history of forces recorded by the crystals. Overall, volcanic quartz crystals preserve complex, overprinted deformation textures that are sometimes detectably influenced by the presence of melt inclusions and heavily influenced by the crystal?s deformation history.

Using synchrotron-sourced X-ray computed microtomography, we measured the properties of trapped inclusions of melt and vapor inside quartz crystals. In super-eruption deposits from Yellowstone, we identified bubbles that would have existed while the magma was stored, prior to eruption. These images provide some of the first physical evidence for volatile supersaturation and retention in a magma reservoir. Quartz-melt surface tension permits bubbles to attach to quartz only when bubbles have been able to homogenously nucleate and grow in the melt. Prior to eruption, the magma thus existed in a bubbly, gas-saturated magma reservoir. The exsolved gases increased magma compressibility, thus preventing the ever-accumulating magma from reaching a critical, eruptive overpressure until it reached a tremendous volume leading to a super-eruption.

This project provided training opportunities for a graduate student. Results were disseminated through refereed publications, at conferences, news outlets, and on the US Geological Survey website.
